results.title: Play Loud
results.brief_description:
The distinctive Australian ‘pub rock’ sound was born in the hotels and bars of our major cities in the 1970s.
In the Melbourne scene, the ‘beer barns’ of the suburbs were complemented by smaller, more intimate venues in the city and inner suburbs of Carlton, Richmond, Fitzroy and St Kilda.
This film - made in his student days by award-winning producer Daniel Scharf - presents a 1979 performance by the Melbourne band ‘Cuban Heels’ at one such venue, ‘Hearts’ in Carlton.
The atmosphere of alcohol, cigarette-smoke and youthful exuberance is captured by the camera as it wanders through the audience and lingers on the dancers.
On stage, the band (led by Steve Connolly, who was later the guitarist with Paul Kelly’s ‘Coloured Girls’ and ‘Messengers’ bands) sings a song that could only be a product of the 1970s - about ‘the system’ and the coming revolution.

results.title: Stories of Rippon Lea Estate
results.brief_description:
Melbourne’s historic Rippon Lea Estate is one of the fabulous locations used in the popular ‘Miss Fisher’ television series. It has also been the venue for an exhibition of the costumes from the series.
Here, staff of the National Trust of Australia (Victoria), who manage the property, talk about its history, its use as a filming location, and the relationship between the producers of the series, the National Trust, and the enthusiastic audiences for the series who have also visited Rippon Lea and the exhibition.

results.title: Stories of Labassa
results.brief_description: The historic mansion ‘Labassa’ in Melbourne has seen many occupants and much activity in its more than 150 years of existence. Bronwyn Worrall, who manages the property for the community heritage organisation, the National Trust of Australia (Victoria), discusses the building’s history as a family residence, a home for ‘hippies’ in the 1970s and its use as a location for a number of films.

results.title: Filming Miss Fisher at the Royal Botanic Gardens Melbourne
results.brief_description:
Tim Entwisle, Director and CEO of the Royal Botanic Gardens Melbourne, introduces the history of the Gardens and Observatory buildings, discussing their initial development in the ‘Marvellous Melbourne’ of the gold rush, and their place in Melbourne’s social and intellectual life.
Tim also recounts the story of the infamous serial killings that took place in the Gardens in the 1920s.

results.title: Miss Fisher's Melbourne: Before and After Visual Effects
results.brief_description: This short work shows how digital special effects are employed to capture ‘before’ and ‘after’ shots to make 2015 Melbourne appear as 1920s Melbourne. These have been produced for ‘Behind the Scenes’ of the series produced by Every Cloud Productions shown on ABC television ‘Miss Fisher’s Murder Mysteries’.

results.description: This short work shows how digital special effects are employed to capture ‘before’ and ‘after’ shots to make 2015 Melbourne appear as 1920s Melbourne. results.title: Miss Fisher's Murder Mysteries: Hispano Suiza
results.creator_credit: Fiona Eagger, Deb Cox, Screen Australia and Every Cloud Productions
results.brief_description:
Learn more about the luxury motor car that appears in the series, Phryne’s red ‘Hispano-Suiza’.
One of the luxury cars of the 1920s, the ‘Hispano-Suiza’ was favoured by royalty, film stars and moguls. The name means “Spanish Swiss”, but the car was manufactured in France, as explained by its owner, Bob, who spent twelve years restoring what had been “just a heap of rusty bits”. His successful restoration adds an authentic glamour to Phryne’s motoring.
results.creator_credit_for_label: Fiona Eagger, Deb Cox, Screen Australia and Every Cloud Productions

results.title: Miss Fisher's Murder Mysteries: Costume Designer Marion Boyce
results.creator_credit: Fiona Eagger, Deb Cox, Screen Australia and Every Cloud Productions
results.brief_description:
Meet Marion Boyce, costume designer for ‘Miss Fisher’s Murder Mysteries’ as she discusses some of the process involved in recreating the look and feel of the 1920s for the popular television series.
Boyce muses on the “sumptuous elegance” of fashion in the nineteen twenties, a period she describes as one of “extreme excess in a lot of ways …. they lived a lot with gay abandon”. She highlights the flattering silhouette bestowed by 1920s men’s fashion of the time, dwells lovingly on the exotic and embellished fabrics of the time, and talks about the use of original pieces - buckles, shoes, feathers and furs - to heighten the authenticity of the costumes.

results.title: Fred's Films. [Luna Park] [excerpt]
results.brief_description: Filmed in the mid 1960s by steam train enthusiast and home movie maker Fred Daley who captures a family outing to the popular sea-side amusement park in St Kilda. ‘Luna Park’ is shown in all its summertime glory with the ‘River Boats’, the ‘Dodgems’, the ‘Rotor’ (a washing spin cycle for humans!), ‘The Spinner’ and of course its famous wooden roller coasters, the ‘Big Dipper’ and the ‘Scenic Railway’. Courageous Fred even films during the ride where you catch a glimpse of Port Phillip Bay from the very top!

results.title: Fred's Films. Models for kids [excerpt]
results.brief_description:
Model railways and miniature steam locomotives have been a great hobby for people passionate about engines and also about ‘quality’ family time. Fred Daley, steam train enthusiast and 8mm movie maker, has captured a meeting of these enthusiasts running their miniature steam engines and pulling the kids along behind them in purpose built ‘carriages’. There is a sense of camaraderie and enthusiasm from the people tending to their fully functioning but small steam locomotives. Both the little kids and the grown up kids seem to be having a lovely day out.
[This film is the final segment from the original film ‘ARC Cement Works, Geelong’.]
